Wearable technology goes back to the 1960s, with helicopter pilots using head-mounted displays. Even the familiar office ID badge is a type of wearable.

 

Now, thanks to recent advances in mobile networks, technology miniaturization and battery improvements, we’re on the verge of an explosion of new, innovative wearables.

 

Glenn Lurie, President and CEO of AT&T Mobility, recently weighed in on wearables at CES 2014:

 

“We are seeing so much interest from consumers - we're excited about [wearables]! We're big believers that your ultimate wearable is a standalone device, a 4G device. We think wearables are going to continue to grow. It's really great innovation."

 

"At our hackathon, we had folks building clothes that had sensors in them that were attached to a hub on your wrist. It's great stuff that we're going to see come into the market.”

Thanks to recent advances in mobile networks, technology miniaturization and battery improvements, we’re on the verge of the next wave of new, innovative wearables.

 

Glenn Lurie, President and CEO of AT&T Mobility, recently weighed in on wearables at CES 2014:

 

“We are seeing so much interest from consumers - we're excited about it! We're big believers that your ultimate wearable is a standalone device, a 4G device. We think wearables are going to continue to grow... it's really great innovation."
